comments.content:
Metric kerning relies on a typeface’s internal metric data, as determined by the typeface designer, to space letters. Optical kerning adjusts spacing based on general letter shapes. Here’s a good discussion of the two with examples, plus links to references:  
 [http://type-ed.com/2013/12/08/metrics-vs-optical/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317155845/http:/type-ed.com/2013/12/08/metrics-vs-optical/ "http://type-ed.com/2013/12/08/metrics-vs-optical/")

Also, I found Jan Tschichold’s <cite>Treasury of Alphabets and Lettering</cite> (1932) to be a useful resource for understanding how kerning should work; his examples of uppercase and lowercase kerning are fairly straightforward. The basic principles still apply to digital type.

For Arabic type, I see no alternative to QB kerning  
 [http://typophile.com/files/QB.pdf](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317155845/http:/typophile.com/files/QB.pdf "http://typophile.com/files/QB.pdf")

What if it is done manually as you can reach a solution professional?

So the question is: Some techniques for MANUAL KERNING?  
words of 3 to 10 characters maximum (eg a logo, a title, a word, a header star)

This topic fascinates me a lot, but so far have found very little, hope your help me Please.

You might find this website useful as well:  
 [http://type.method.ac/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150317155845/http:/type.method.ac/ "http://type.method.ac/")

Test your skills at kerning against professionals, and see where you differ.
The classic on the subject is Geoffrey Dowding's _Finer Points in the spacing and arrangement of type_, Wace & Company Ltd., London 1954 (3rd ed. 1966).
